results.title: Somethin' about Scandanavia: as told by a Danish boy
results.creator_credit: Bent Barfod and Government Film Committee of Denmark
results.brief_description: This animated film gives a lighthearted resume of Norway, Sweden, Denmark and Iceland; their history and geography, main products, standard of living and dependence upon trade and co-operation for prosperity. Based on an idea by Carl T. Dreyer. Animation by Berge Hamberg.

results.title: Someone looks at something
results.brief_description: The title of this documentary is taken from the name that well-known Australian artist Peter Tyndall gives to all his work - `Detail’. While Peter is best known as a painter, he has also produced drawings, comic-strips, photographs, super 8 films, computer imagery, music and live performance pieces. Examining his work in a wide range of mediums since 1971, the film is also a thoughtful look at the creative process and development of an artist’s work. An excellent discussion film for upper secondary school.

results.title: Somebody now: 'Nobody's Children' seven years on
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, David Goldie and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: This film follows on from Nobody’s children”, an expose of homeless youth in inner Sydney. Seven years later, the producers have located two of the children from the original film in order to discover if things have improved for them and what impact being homeless had on their lives. The strong message that emerges is that even though the homeless person may experience a change in their socio-economic status at some point, this does not change the person they are inside. They still face the same emotional issues and burdens they had while they were homeless; unless they receive help, they will simply perpetuate the same situations over and over.

results.title: Some of our voices
results.brief_description: A special television program dramatising the growth of cultural centres throughout the United States. The program includes performances by Leonard Bernstein, Harry Belafonte, Marian Anderson, Pable Casals and other important performing artists from the ballet and repertory theatre. Narrated by John Forsythe.

results.title: Some like it rough
results.creator_credit: Richard Massingham, Lewis Grant Wallace and British and American Forces for the Ministry of Information
results.brief_description: An American and a British soldier meet by chance and very soon begin to argue about the relative merits, especially the “toughness” of British rugger and American gridiron football. Each man then takes part in the game played by the other man’s fellow-countrymen, and from this experiment both of them barely escape alive. Presented in a humorous fashion.

results.title: Some creatures of the Barrier Reef
results.brief_description: A study of some of the unique marine animals of the Great Barrier Reef, which is noted for the variety and vivid colouring of its fauna. Also presents a general picture of the geographical formation of the reef.

results.title: Some babies die
results.brief_description: An exploration of stillbirth and neonatal grief by sharing the experience of two families. One family, under the guidance of a specialised medical team, undergoes an unusual counselling process to help them resolve their grief more easily. They are encouraged to spend time seeing, holding and touching their dead baby. This is a film which questions our attitudes on death.

results.title: Some Australian birds
results.creator_credit: S.T. Evans, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and CSIRO
results.brief_description: The work of the wild life survey section of the CSIRO. Includes close study of the function of the lyrebird’s mimicry; the nesting habits of the mallee fowl, a shy bird which builds a high mound; the king penguin which lives on Macquarie Island in large colonies, and the Tasmanian mutton birds which support a small industry.
